title: Trump's biggest threat looms - and it's not impeachment
text:
But it's one that also shows the President refusing to take even the slightest defensive shuffle. There is no evidence the Bidens have done anything wrong. Former US special envoy for Ukraine Kurt Volker told congressional investigators on Thursday that he warned Trump's personal fixer, Rudy Giuliani, that claims of Biden misconduct were not credible.

No matter.

“China should start an investigation into the Bidens,” Trump declared. “What happened in China is just about as bad as what happened with ... Ukraine.”

Moments later he doubled down on his demand from Ukraine.

“I would say that President Zelensky, if it were me, I would recommend that they start an investigation into the Bidens,” he said. “Because nobody has any doubt that they weren’t crooked.”

To his critics, Trump’s brazenness is breathtaking. He is openly flouting what Democrats and a growing number of Americans regard as an abuse of the presidential office.

Normalising corrupt behaviour

Trump is a master at flinging dirt, and he is more than willing to co-opt foreigners to his cause – even after the extraordinary events of the 2016 presidential election, which Robert Mueller's report showed was riddled with Russian interference.

Advertisement

That Trump feels at ease to speak so openly about his attempts to cajole foreign countries for personal gain raises two possibilities.

The first and most probable is that Trump has chosen a strategy of normalising his behaviour – to make it seem as routine for any president as putting on a suit and tie.

As he says of the transcript of his conversation with Zelensky, which set the impeachment train steaming, it was “beautiful” and perfect.

This approach will work among his supporters, and history shows he wouldn’t be the first to tangle with foreign powers for political gain. The story of Richard Nixon’s efforts to sabotage Vietnam peace talks in the final weeks of the 1968 presidential campaign continues to emerge as research is undertaken in the era. Likewise, it’s always been passing interesting that Iran released American hostages immediately after Ronald Reagan's swearing-in in 1981, ending a crisis that destroyed Jimmy Carter’s presidency.

Trump’s behaviour is in some ways more dramatic because he’s putting it on the front page and every cable TV chyron in the land.

The second possibility is that Trump genuinely doesn’t believe he has done anything wrong. In which case, the President is writing the articles of impeachment himself. All the Democrats need do is hit copy-paste.

Trump’s approach over the past few days has been to dial the invective up to 11. He has called the leading Democrat impeachment investigator, Adam Schiff, a “low life” who should be hounded from office for “treason”.

Advertisement

He continues to wail against the “fake media”, and – in yet another presidential first – took to Twitter and slammed his enemies’ pursuit as “BULLSHIT”.

The president has even invoked the possibility of America sliding into “civil war” if he’s hounded from office.

It’s a scorched-earth strategy that leaves no space for a Nixon-style pre-emptive resignation and final climb into Marine One. Republicans are acutely aware that Trump will take the party down with him. Conservatives who may oppose his actions are too fearful to cross the President and his rusted-on supporters.

President Donald Trump is refusing to take even the slightest defensive shuffle. Bloomberg

The result is that America is locked into a preordained process. Voters are divided pretty much down the middle – as a number of polls have indicated in recent days.

Like a black hole, impeachment is sucking all matter towards darkness.

A congealing threat

But the crisis in the White House and Congress is happening just as another threat begins to congeal – one that may be even more dangerous for Trump.

Advertisement

Warning lights are again flashing on Wall Street that the US economy is slowing sharply under the burden of the trade war and a faltering global economy.

Manufacturing numbers – a barometer on a sector of the economy critical to the President’s re-election – are turning south fast.

Tariffs continue to ratchet up, extending the burden on the American midwest, where farmers have been asked to carry the can for the conflict with Beijing.

The figures are so bad that many analysts believe manufacturing and agriculture are now in recession. Add to that a damaging industrial dispute at General Motors which is chipping away at the economy of Michigan – a must-win for Trump in 2020.

From New Orleans came news that Bayou Steel Group filed for bankruptcy. Louisiana Governor John Bel Edwards said the company was "particularly vulnerable" to tariffs because it uses imported scrap.

While many of those portents are overshadowed or masked by the still-strong US consumer spending, equity investors are again asking how long it can last as negatives pile up.

The Atlanta Fed’s real-time GDP growth estimate slipped this week to 1.8 per cent from 2.1 per cent a week earlier. That’s a far cry from the 3 per cent, 4 per cent or even more that Trump promised.

On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average shed more than 1000 points over the past three days.

Advertisement

“Anxiety over the economy, fuelled by the media’s fixation on recession, is a huge threat to Trump,” says Washington observer Greg Valliere, an analyst at AGF.

The turmoil in the markets has generated a predictable response from the White House: Trump has again hit out at Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell and blamed the Democratic impeachment process for falling stocks.

Almost certain are more Fed rate cuts, further weakening America’s policy reserves should the economy stall early next year.

But more significantly the shaky economic news and political firestorm are driving home how badly Washington is missing in action.

“The spectre of impeachment and the perception of an embattled President Trump will make China even more reluctant to offer… structural concessions, thereby decreasing the chances of a substantive deal anytime soon, prolonging uncertainty, and risking escalation," says Libby Cantrill, a public policy analyst at PIMCO.

On the brink of losing control

In the meantime, Trump shows signs of being consumed by the political battle. Little else is coming out of the White House.

His press conference on a podium alongside Finland’s President Sauli Niinistö on Wednesday was stunning. Trump seethed at his enemies; his anger seemed at times to come close to boiling over.

Advertisement

He lashed out at a reporter from Reuters. For the first time in more than a year of watching Trump press conferences at length, this correspondent had the unnerving sense of a man on the brink of losing control.

Niinistö did his best to keep things from going completely off the rails on a day when Trump was thundering about civil wars and treason.

The visitor opened his remarks by mentioning how he had spent some free time visiting Washington’s most significant museums, places that tell the story of America's special uniqueness. He went to American History Museum, the African American History Museum and the National Museum of the American Indian.

“Mr President,” he continued, “you have here a great democracy. Keep it going on.”

Subtle as a Finnish winter.

Trump loves a political fight. Impeachment gives him a vehicle to lash out at his enemies and galvanise supporters.

But impeachment could ultimately turn out to be a sideshow.

“The Senate is unlikely to convict Trump. So it’s the economy that poses the greatest risk to him,” says Valliere.
description: The Commander-in-Chief is throwing haymakers at Democrats, but the real danger is the economy.
